title: "I like arguing against quotes that nobody said ever"
body: 〜 Every upvote whore thread on this board

replies.body:
"I'm going to paraphrase something in a way that is biased to my argument" - most threads
"I'm going to selectively quote a rioter, leaving out all context, to farm anti riot upvotes" - the rest

Don't most people who debate try to get their argument biased towards them? I mean most will give the benefit of the doubt too. The point of an argument is usually to persuade people in your opinion. I could be wrong though. That's usually what I try to do.

That's how arguments work in real life; you just need to convince someone through any means possible. But the "scholarly ideal" is touted as something that's scrutinized by a group of reputables in the field and still manages to convince them because the argument doesn't shy away from dissent.
You can do so without distorting the truth. Here on the internet, someone will always b there to call u out on it.
I will agree I see a lot of people try to distort the truth, so it's only fair they get called out on it. This includes the community and Riot.

yha i was anti riot for a long time and on some issues still am. I try to make sure that the rest of the anti riot guys don't completely do this...Of course I'll back them up if they paraphrased something correctly.

A while back riot stated plain and simple they would not nerf lee due to community backlash, and someone posted a paraphrase from (lyte perhaps i can't remember which rioter it was) when they ignored the community about the mord rework. a lot of people called bullshit without looking anything up till I stepped in and showed them a post from riot about it and then they all said this was a good way to describe the paragraph the rioter wrote.

TL:DR don't paraphrase just to meet your needs.
